text:
For lack of playground facilities the young of the city's poor neighborhoods resort to shack buildings on empty lots for their entertainment.

View 1: Avenue A and 67th St., Sept. 12, 1925
View 2: Fulton Street, Brooklyn, Nov. 26, 1927
View 3: Washington and Bethune Sts., June 24, 1933

P. L. Sperr, photographer
title: Recreation and hobbies - Children. [Manhattan: Avenue A - 67th Street.]

text:
(1)
67th Street, north side, west from and including York Avenue. At the date of this picture York Avenue was known as Avenue A.
February 13, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date and showing demolition prior to the construction of a park on this site. Shown across clearance is the north side of East 68th Street, west from and including First to and including Second Aves.
September 25, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 2, and showing a further view eastward on East 68th Street, to but not including York Ave.
September 25, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

February 13, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue (Avenue A), west side, from 67th to 68th Streets, showing a skating rink and the old cigar factory, on the S.W. corner of 68th Street, where Robt. Burns cigars used to be made. It was built around 1905, and now belongs to Seidenberg and Company. It is shortly to be demolished, and around the same time the rink will be converted into tennis courts.
As late as 1902 these plots were occupied by a stone yard, probably belonging to the B. & G. Williams stone yard across the Avenue. February 13, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) 67th Street, and York Avenue, New York Hospital under construction.

September 1930.

(2) Same, ten years later.

P.L.Speer.

September 29, 1940.

(1) 67th Street, and York Avenue, New York Hospital under construction.

September 1930.

(2) Same, ten years later.

P.L.Speer.

September 29, 1940.

Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, York Avenue, east side, at 67th Street. The new laboratory is nearing completion. Its south side is in line with 67th Street, which was permanently closed (about 1926) east of York Avenue. In the right foreground is shown part of the old playground which used to occupy the block from 67th to 68th Streets. The construction beginning at the extreme left of this picture is on the north side of 68th Street.
July 31, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue, east side, from 67th to 68th Streets, showing the playground of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, with a new laboratory building under construction for the Rockefeller Institute, in the right background, and the new New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College under construction on the north side of 68th Street. This playground, which is now about to give way to tennis courts, has occupied this site since around 1920; around 1885 to 1905 this was the stone yard of B. A. & G. N. W. Williams.
July 31, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue, east side, from 67th to 71st Streets, showing construction of New York Hospital and Cornell Medical Center, and playground of Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, on S.E. corner of 68th Street, which is shortly to be made over into tennis courts.
July 31, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

67th Street, north side, between York and First Aves., showing a general view northeast. Prominent buildings shown are the New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College.
June 30, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

York Avenue, (formerly Avenue "A"), west side, south from E. 69th to 67th Streets, showing prominently the new Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases.

This structure occupies the block, west from this thoroughfare to First Avenue, between 67th and 68th Streets. At the right are tennis courts between 68th and 69th Streets. To the left are apartment houses at the S.W. corner of 67th Street.

November 13, 1939

Gift of George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division
